CSS101.name: Introduction to Crop Science
CSS101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSS101.description: Principles of crop production including integrated crop management. Sustainable agriculture. International agriculture. Environmental challenges to crop production.
CSS101.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS101L.name: Introduction to Crop Science Laboratory
CSS101L.description: Identification of crops, seeds, plant structures; plant nutrient deficiency symptoms; crop growth stages and environmental stresses including pests, nutrients, drought, and temperature. Field trips required.
CSS101L.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS105.name: Agricultural Industries Seminar
CSS105.description: Preparation for academic and professional success. Introduction to opportunities in the agriculture industry.
CSS105.restrictions: Open to agricultural technology students in the Agricultural Industries Major.

CSS110.name: Computer Applications in Agronomy
CSS110.description: Use of computers in agriculture. Basic computer operating systems. Management and use of storage media. Laboratory experience in word processing, spreadsheets, databases, programming languages, networking, and software related to agriculture.
CSS110.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

CSS120.name: Issues in Food and Agriculture
CSS120.description: Current and historical issues impacting food and agriculture.
CSS120.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS124.name: Introduction to Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
CSS124.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSS124.description: Contemporary research and movements involving agricultural and food system sustainability. Socio-cultural factors influencing food and agriculture.
CSS124.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS126.name: Introduction to Weed Management
CSS126.description: Biology, identification, and management of weeds.
CSS126.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

CSS135.name: Crop Scouting and Investigation
CSS135.description: Crop scouting and agricultural clientele interactions for improved crop management. Offered first ten weeks of semester.
CSS135.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS143.name: Introduction to Soil Science
CSS143.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSS143.description: S oil and its impact on plant growth, plant and water relations, drainage, nutrients, soil as a resource, and erosion control techniques.
CSS143.restrictions: Open to agricultural technology students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

CSS151.name: Seed and Grain Quality
CSS151.description: Principles and practices of producing, conditioning, testing and marketing field crop seed. Grain grading and quality evaluation. Offered first ten weeks of semester.
CSS151.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS171.name: Operations Budgeting for Golf Course Managers
CSS171.description: Budgeting. Financial analysis. Purchasing and materials management for golf course operations. Offered first ten weeks of semester.

CSS178.name: Turfgrass Irrigation
CSS178.description: Turfgrass irrigation systems. Installation and maintenance including water management. Offered first ten weeks of semester.

CSS181.name: Pesticide and Fertilizer Application Technology
CSS181.description: Effective and efficient application of pesticides and fertilizers to turf and ornamentals. Pesticide handling, legal, and environmental concerns. Calibration of equipment. Offered first ten weeks of semester.

CSS192.name: Professional Development Seminar I
CSS192.description: Career development, critical issues analysis, resume writing, scientific presentations and public speaking in crop and soil sciences.
CSS192.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Plant, Soil and Microbial Sciences.

CSS201.name: Forage Crops
CSS201.description: Forage crop production, management, and utilization; crop identification; soil fertilization; planting and harvesting of grasses and legumes.
CSS201.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS202.name: World of Turf
CSS202.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS202.description: Role of turf in society and the environment. Principles underlying establishment and maintenance of turf on athletic fields, parks, home lawns, and golf courses. Aesthetic, safety, and economic aspects of turfgrass management practices.

CSS202L.name: World of Turf Lab
CSS202L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS202L.description: Turfgrass identification. Site analysis and recommendations. On campus facility and venue visits. Mowing equipment and practices. Turf establishment. Soil cultivation and amendments. Fertilizer and pest management. Field trips required.

CSS210.name: Fundamentals of Soil Science
CSS210.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSS210.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS212.name: Advanced Crop Production
CSS212.description: Systems approach to production of field crops including corn, soybeans, small grains, sugar beets, and dry beans.
CSS212.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS222.name: New Horizons in Biotechnology
CSS222.description: Perspectives on biotechnology for safer food production, environmental quality, and improved human health. Impacts of biotechnology on the national economy. Political and ethical ramifications of applied biotechnology.
CSS222.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS224.name: Sustainable Farm and Food Systems Field Studies
CSS224.description: Field visits to farm and food system operations that utilize sustainable practices in Michigan. Offered first half of semester.
CSS224.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or agricultural technology students.

CSS226L.name: Weed Science Laboratory
CSS226L.description: Weed and weed seed collection and identification. Mechanical and chemical tools involved in managing weeds. Herbicide application and calibration. Weed and crop selectivity, crop injury symptoms.
CSS226L.prerequisite: ((CSS 126 or concurrently) or (CSS 326 or concurrently)) and (CSS 101 or CSS 232 or HRT 203 or HRT 109)

CSS232.name: Turfgrass Management
CSS232.description: Turfgrass utilization, identification, establishment and management principles. Responses to various cultural practices.

CSS251.name: Organic Farming Principles and Practices
CSS251.description: History and principles of organic farming. Farms as ecological systems. Certification process and agencies. Organic matter management, the soil food web, and nutrient availability. Biodiversity, crop rotations, plant competition, ground cover, and plant health. Integrating crops and animals. Organic animal husbandry. Field trip required.

CSS262.name: Turfgrass Management Seminar
CSS262.description: Presentations by turf students and industry professionals. Topics include internship experiences, technical expertise, and keys to successful career pathways.

CSS264.name: Golf Course Design and Construction Techniques
CSS264.description: Concepts and theory of golf course design and construction including location, space, topography, clientele, and environmental concerns.

CSS267.name: Performance Turf Design and Construction
CSS267.description: Performance turfgrass design, construction, renovation and establishment principles.

CSS269.name: Turfgrass Strategies: Integration and Synthesis
CSS269.description: Issues in turfgrass management including employee relations, cultural, and environmental problems. Offered first ten weeks of semester.

CSS272.name: Turfgrass Soil Fertility
CSS272.description: Soil-plant relationships, soil acidity and alkalinity, macro- and micro-nutrients, fertilizer materials, soil fertility, evaluations, and fertilizer programming. Offered first ten weeks of semester.

CSS282.name: Turfgrass Physiology
CSS282.description: Physiological principles of turfgrass growth and development. Water relations, light, temperature, respiration, photosynthesis, mineral nutrition, and hormone action. Impact of mowing, cultivation, and traffic on turfgrass growth. Offered first ten weeks of semester.
CSS282.prerequisite: (CSS 232) Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

CSS290.name: Independent Study in Crop and Soil Science
CSS290.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS290.description: Field, laboratory, or library research problems.
CSS290.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology. Approval of department; application required.

CSS294.name: Issues in International Agriculture
CSS294.description: Global issues related to food production, soil resources and sustainability of agriculture in developing and developed countries.
CSS294.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
CSS294.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

CSS313.name: Data Interpretation and Writing in the Agronomic Sciences
CSS313.description: Data analysis, interpretation, integration, and technical writing in agronomic sciences.

CSS326.name: Weed Science
CSS326.description: Weed biology and ecology. Integrated weed management including cultural, mechanical, biological, and chemical control practices. Herbicide mode of action, selectivity in plants, environmental considerations.
CSS326.restrictions: Not open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

CSS330.name: Soil Chemistry
CSS330.description: Organic and inorganic soil processes including mineralogy, adsorption, desorption, and precipitation. Chemistry of soil organic matter and inorganic soil components.

CSS331.name: Water Management in Agriculture and Food Systems
CSS331.description: Principles of water management, use efficiency and conservation in agricultural production, natural resources and food processing facilities. Best agricultural water management practices, water rights, irrigation scheduling, irrigation systems selection, evaluation and management and drainage principles. Large scale water use, management and conservation in food processing.
CSS331.prerequisite: MTH 103 or MTH 124 or MTH 132 or LB 118

CSS340.name: Applied Soil Physics
CSS340.description: Soil physical properties including solids, water, air, and heat. Transport processes in soil.

CSS343.name: Principles of Precision Agriculture
CSS343.description: Global positioning systems (GPS), yield monitors, and computer software. Analysis and interpretation of field maps. Variable-rate application. Economics of precision agriculture.
CSS343.prerequisite: MTH 103 or MTH 114 or MTH 116 or MTH 124 or MTH 132

CSS350.name: Introduction to Plant Genetics
CSS350.description: Fundamentals of plant genetics with applications to agriculture and natural resources.

CSS360.name: Soil Biology
CSS360.description: Overview of organismal diversity and biological soil processes. Role of macroorganisms and microorganisms in soil processing, including nutrient cycling.

CSS424.name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems: Integration and Synthesis
CSS424.description: Biogeochemical and socio-economic aspects of food, fiber, and fuel production. Environmental impacts and social context. Experiential learning projects.
CSS424.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSS425.name: Microbial Ecology
CSS425.description: Microbial population and community interactions. Microbial activities in natural systems, including associations with plants or animals.

CSS431.name: International Agricultural Systems
CSS431.description: World production capacity for food, fiber and biofuel as related to soil, biology and climatic resources. Principles and case studies of sustainable systems presented from developing and developed countries. Emerging issues in agricultural globalization and biodiversity.
CSS431.prerequisite: (ANR 250 or ISS 310 or ISS 315 or ISS 318 or ISS 320 or ISS 330A or ISS 330B or ISS 330C or ISS 336) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

CSS441.name: Plant Breeding and Biotechnology
CSS441.description: Plant improvement by genetic manipulation. History of plant breeding. Traditional and biotechnological means of improving plant cultivars by genetic manipulation. Importance of plant breeding to our food system, economy, and environment.

CSS442.name: Agricultural Ecology
CSS442.description: Ecological principles in the design and management of agricultural ecosystems. Integration of ecological factors regulating crop and rangeland productivity.
CSS442.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSS445.name: Evolution (W)
CSS445.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS445.description: Processes of evolutionary change in animals, plants. Microbes. Population genetics, microevolution, speciation, adaptive radiation, macroevolution. Origin of Homo sapiens.
CSS445.prerequisite: (IBIO 341 or CSS 350) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

CSS451.name: Biotechnology Applications for Plant Breeding and Genetics
CSS451.description: Principles, concepts, and techniques of agricultural plant biotechnology. Recombinant DNA technology, plant molecular biology and transformation in relation to plant improvement.
CSS451.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSS452.name: Watershed Concepts
CSS452.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS452.description: Watershed hydrology and management. The hydrologic cycle, water quality, aquatic ecosystems, and social systems. Laws and institutions for managing water resources.

CSS455.name: Environmental Pollutants in Soil and Water
CSS455.description: Environmental sources, physiochemical and biological processes, management of plant nutrients, heavy metals, organic contaminants, pesticides and pharmaceuticals in soil and water.
CSS455.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSS461.name: Seminar in Plant, Animal and Microbial Biotechnology
CSS461.description: Current applications of plant, animal and microbial biotechnology in agriculture and related industries. Technologies under development and factors associated with moving from laboratory to product development. Field trips required.
CSS461.prerequisite: (ANS 425 or concurrently) or (BE 360 or concurrently) or (CSS 451 or concurrently) or (MMG 445 or concurrently)

CSS464.name: Statistics for Biologists
CSS464.description: Biological random variables. Estimation of population parameters. Testing hypotheses. Linear correlation and regression. Analyses of counted and measured data to compare several biological groups including contingency tables and analysis of variance.
CSS464.prerequisite: MTH 103 or MTH 110 or MTH 116 or MTH 132

CSS467.name: BioEnergy Feedstock Production
CSS467.description: Agronomic, economic, technological, and environmental principles involved in bioenergy feedstock production. Cultivation, harvest, transportation, and storage of agricultural and forest biomass.
CSS467.prerequisite: MTH 103 or MTH 116 or MTH 124 or MTH 132 or LB 118 or MTH 152H or MTH 133 or MTH 153H or LB 119

CSS470.name: Soil Resources
CSS470.description: Evaluation of the properties, genesis, and classification of soil resources to assist in making land-use decisions.
CSS470.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

CSS477.name: Pesticides in Pest Management
CSS477.description: Chemistry, modes of action, product development and regulation of pesticides. Environmental and social aspects of pesticide use.
CSS477.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

CSS480.name: Soil Fertility and Management
CSS480.description: Comprehensive management of agricultural soils. Soil fertility, including liming and fertilizer materials and other nutrient sources. Site specific soil management. Environmental impacts including soil erosion, runoff, and organic matter mineralization.
CSS480.prerequisite: CSS 210 and (CSS 330 or CSS 340 or CSS 360 or (CSS 470 or concurrently))
CSS480.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Agronomy minor or in the Crop and Soil Sciences major.

CSS486.name: Biotechnology in Agriculture: Applications and Ethical Issues
CSS486.description: Current and future roles of biotechnology in agriculture
CSS486.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

CSS488.name: Agricultural Cropping Systems: Integration and Problem Solving
CSS488.description: Integration and synthesis of agronomic and related concepts in agricultural cropping systems. Problem solving and application of information.
CSS488.prerequisite: (CSS 101 and CSS 210) and completion of Tier I writing requirement.
CSS488.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Agronomy minor or in the Crop and Soil Sciences major.

CSS490.name: Independent Study
CSS490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS490.description: Individual work on field, laboratory, or library research problem of special interest to the student.

CSS491.name: Special Topics
CSS491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS491.description: Topics from crop production, crop physiology, turfgrass management, organic soils, turfgrass soils, soil fertility, plant and soil relationships, genetics, biotechnology, environmental science, or sustainable agriculture.

CSS492.name: Professional Development Seminar II
CSS492.description: Synthesis, integration and application of agronomic principles to current issues in agronomy via discussion and oral and written communication.
CSS492.prerequisite: (CSS 192 or CSS 262) and (CSS 210 and completion of Tier I Writing requirement)
CSS492.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of Plant, Soil and Microbial Sciences.

CSS493.name: Professional Internship in Crop and Soil Sciences
CSS493.description: Supervised professional experiences in crop and soil sciences.
CSS493.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
CSS493.restrictions: Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 6 credits in all enrollments for any or all of these courses

CSS499.name: Undergraduate Research
CSS499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS499.description: Faculty supervised research in a selected area of crop and soil sciences or environmental soil science.

CSS802.name: Weed Biology
CSS802.description: Weed biology, including weed seed production and dispersal and seed fate. Weed life history traits and ecophysiology, including invasive species. Data collection in weed ecology research.

CSS805.name: Herbicide Action and Metabolism
CSS805.description: Properties and characteristics of herbicides. Processes involved in herbicide action, transport, and fate in plants and soils.

CSS814.name: Advanced Statistics for Biologists
CSS814.description: Concepts of reducing experimental error for biological and agricultural research. Covariance, randomized block designs, latin squares, split plots, repeated-measures designs, regression applications, and response surface designs. Analyses using statistical software.

CSS819.name: Advanced Plant Breeding
CSS819.description: Genetic expectations resulting from breeding strategies with cross- and self-pollinated crop plants. Germplasm collections, mapping populations, and modifications of reproductive biology useful for crop improvement.

CSS820.name: Plant Reproductive Biology and Polyploidy
CSS820.description: Genetic processes underlying variations in plant reproductive biology and polyploidy. Utilization of these characteristics in plant breeding.

CSS840.name: Soil Physics
CSS840.description: Physical properties of soil including texture, structure, consistency, aeration, moisture content, and temperature. Quantitative measurement of plant growth. Agronomic and engineering practices.
CSS840.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CSS846.name: Integrated Climate and Cropping System Modeling
CSS846.description: Crop simulation modeling for water and nutrient use under resource limitations and varying climatic conditions.

CSS850.name: Soil Chemistry
CSS850.description: Ion activities, ionic exchange and equilibrium reactions. Soil pH, macro- and micronutrients, saline soils and availability of nutrients to plants.
CSS850.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CSS853.name: Plant Mineral Nutrition
CSS853.description: Inorganic ion transport in plant cells and tissues. Physiological responses and adaptation to problem soils. Genetic diversity in nutrient uptake and use by plants. Physiological roles of elemental nutrients in crop growth.

CSS863.name: Mineral-Water Interactions
CSS863.description: Mineralogy, petrology and geochemistry of fluid-rock reactions in geologic, sedimentary and geochemical cycles. Rock and mineral weathering, soil formation, genesis and burial diagenesis of sediments and sedimentary rocks, and metamorphism.
CSS863.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Crop and Soil Sciences or Department of Geological Sciences or Department of Geography.

CSS865.name: Environmental Fate of Organic Contaminants in Soils
CSS865.description: Chemistry and biology of toxicants in soils as determinants of environmental fate.

CSS880.name: Scientific Communication and Professional Development
CSS880.description: Interactive professional experiences including grant preproposal preparation and presentation, scientific presentations, mock position interviews, and resume preparation.

CSS890.name: Independent Study
CSS890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS890.description: Individual study on field, laboratory, or library research.
CSS890.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CSS891.name: Current Topics in Ecology and Evolution
CSS891.description: Presentation and critical evaluation of theoretical and empirical developments in ecology and evolutionary biology by visiting scientists.

CSS891B.name: Selected Topics in Plant Breeding and Genetics
CSS891B.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS891B.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Plant Breeding and Genetics major or Genetics major. Approval of department.

CSS892.name: Plant Breeding and Genetics Seminar
CSS892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS892.description: Experience in review, organization, oral presentation, and analysis of research.

CSS892B.name: Ecological Food and Farming Systems Seminar
CSS892B.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CSS892B.description: Experiential learning, and multidisciplinary and applied research, in ecological food and farming systems.

CSS893.name: Selected Topics
CSS893.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS893.description: Selected topics in crop and soil sciences of current interest and importance.
CSS893.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CSS899.name: Master's Thesis Research
CSS899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS899.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Plant, Soil and Microbial Sciences.

CSS941.name: Quantitative Genetics in Plant Breeding
CSS941.description: Theoretical and genetic basis of statistical analysis of quantitative traits using genetic markers. Computational tools for the study of quantitative traits.

CSS999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
CSS999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CSS999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Plant, Soil and Microbial Sciences.
